description: Protests in Detroit following the death of George Floyd are to continue for a 12th straight night Tuesday, with marchers getting an update from organizers about a meeting earlier in the day with Mayor Mike Duggan. More: Detroit protesters present Duggan with long list of demands: What's on it. Marchers prepare to gather at 4 p.m. at Detroit Police Headquarters...
text:
(Follow along below for updates on the protest through the night.)

Protests in Detroit following the death of George Floyd are to continue for a
12th straight night Tuesday, with marchers getting an update from organizers
about a meeting earlier in the day with Mayor Mike Duggan.

The march comes on the same day as the funeral for Floyd, who died two weeks
ago in Minneapolis after a police officer kneeled on his neck. Hundreds have
been gathering each night for protests of violence against African-Americans.
An 8 p.m. curfew was lifted because protests In Detroit have been peaceful.

<strong style="margin-right:3px;">More: Protesters congregate on night 11 at
site of infamous killings in 1967

<strong style="margin-right:3px;">More: Detroit protesters present Duggan with
long list of demands: What's on it

Tuesday's march comes after a powerful rally Monday at the site of the former
Algiers Motel on Woodward, where three black teenagers were killed in late
July 1967. Three Detroit police officers were acquitted in their deaths.

3:30 p.m. Feel the heat

Marchers prepare to gather at 4 p.m. at Detroit Police Headquarters near
Michigan and Third for a 12th straight night of protest in Detroit.

They'll hear about a meeting that organizers had with Mayor Mike Duggan hours
earlier.

Two of the group's representatives, Tristan Taylor and Nakia-Renne Wallace,
said earlier that the group has a list of demands, prioritizing the first 11.

Some of those top 11 demands include: defund and demilitarize the police; End
Project Greenlight, a public-private community partnership that uses real-time
camera surveillance throughout the city, and facial recognition software to
identify suspects; drop all charges and citations against protesters; do not
carry out eviction orders, and prosecute and fire any police officer involved
in police brutality.

Staff writer Frank Witsil contributed to this report.

Contact Christina Hall: [chall@freepress.com](mailto:chall@freepress.com).
Follow her on Twitter: @challreporter.

This article originally appeared on Detroit Free Press: 12th day of protests
in Detroit comes after organizers met with Mayor Duggan

___

Visit the Detroit Free Press at www.freep.com

Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC.

title: 12th day of protests in Detroit comes after organizers met with Mayor Duggan [Detroit Free Press]
html:
(Follow along below for updates on the protest through the night.)

Protests in Detroit following the death of George Floyd are to continue for a 12th straight night Tuesday, with marchers getting an update from organizers about a meeting earlier in the day with Mayor Mike Duggan.

The march comes on the same day as the funeral for Floyd, who died two weeks ago in Minneapolis after a police officer kneeled on his neck. Hundreds have been gathering each night for protests of violence against African-Americans. An 8 p.m. curfew was lifted because protests In Detroit have been peaceful.

<strong style="margin-right:3px;">More: Protesters congregate on night 11 at site of infamous killings in 1967

<strong style="margin-right:3px;">More: Detroit protesters present Duggan with long list of demands: What's on it

Tuesday's march comes after a powerful rally Monday at the site of the former Algiers Motel on Woodward, where three black teenagers were killed in late July 1967. Three Detroit police officers were acquitted in their deaths.

3:30 p.m. Feel the heat

Marchers prepare to gather at 4 p.m. at Detroit Police Headquarters near Michigan and Third for a 12th straight night of protest in Detroit.

They'll hear about a meeting that organizers had with Mayor Mike Duggan hours earlier.

Two of the group's representatives, Tristan Taylor and Nakia-Renne Wallace, said earlier that the group has a list of demands, prioritizing the first 11.

Some of those top 11 demands include: defund and demilitarize the police; End Project Greenlight, a public-private community partnership that uses real-time camera surveillance throughout the city, and facial recognition software to identify suspects; drop all charges and citations against protesters; do not carry out eviction orders, and prosecute and fire any police officer involved in police brutality.

Staff writer Frank Witsil contributed to this report.

Contact Christina Hall: chall@freepress.com. Follow her on Twitter: @challreporter.

This article originally appeared on Detroit Free Press: 12th day of protests in Detroit comes after organizers met with Mayor Duggan
